sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client formerly known as Ximian Red Carpet, is a program designed to help you manage the software you have on your computer. It can help you install, update, and remove programs, without making you keep track of dependencies and conflicts yourself. It works with the package management rules your operating system already has, so you can use it alongside unrelated command-line tools.

note.title: What is a Package?
note.para: Software for most versions of Linux is shipped as a package file. Each package contains a set of files that constitute the software itself, plus additional information about what the software is, what requirements it has, and where it should be installed. Proper packaging makes software easier to install, upgrade, or remove, and can help manage the interdependencies among various programs.
ZENworks Linux Management supports only the RPM (Red Hat Package Manager) package format, which is used by most distributions.

note.title: What are Catalogs?
note.para: ZENworks Linux Management groups software into catalogs. You can subscribe to catalogs that interest you, and ignore those that do not.

To subscribe to a catalog, select EditCatalog Subscriptions or click the Catalogs button on the toolbar. A window will open to show you the list of available catalogs. Check the box next to a catalog to subscribe.

You can also mount a directory as a catalog, adding all packages within the directory to the catalog. Click File, then click Mount Directory. Specify the catalog name and browse to the directory that you want to mount as a catalog. Select the Look for Packages Recursively option to search the selected directory's subdirectories.

listitem.para: A network connection is required for the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client to connect to a ZENworks Server and to gain access to the catalogs and packages it provides. Without a connection, the client can still perform installs, updates, and removals of packages on the local machine. To install from a file, click File Install from File . For information on removing software, see .
To install, update, or remove software, you must enter your system's root password. If you do not have root privileges, you may only view the software installed on your system.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: To start using the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client, click SystemSoftware Update from the menu panel, or type red-carpet at the command line. Enter your root password when prompted.

The default view of the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client window has two major sections that display information. On the right side, there is a list of software packages. On the left side of the window is a list of transactions. As you use the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client, you will choose software from the package list to install or remove, adding the installation or removal to the list of actions.
If you do not see any packages listed under any of the tabs, you may need to activate services. For more information, see .
For detailed information about a package, select it and click the Information button.

tip.title: Sort Order
tip.para: To change the way information is sorted, click the headers at the top of the columns of data. For example, to sort software in alphabetical order by package name, click the Package header. Click again to sort in reverse alphabetical order.

sect1.para: To select a package, click it with the left mouse button. You can select multiple packages by holding down Ctrl and clicking, or select a range using Shift. To select all packages in the list, press CtrlA.

To mark a package for installation or removal, click the Mark for Installation or Mark for Removal buttons at the bottom of the screen. You can also click the Action column to choose an action for each package.

note.title: How Many Kinds of Transactions Are There?
note.para: There are two transactions you can perform using the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client: installation and removal. An upgrade is essentially the removal of the package's old version and installation of the new one. Therefore, there are only two actions you can choose: Mark for Installation and Mark for Removal.

Where appropriate, the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client displays upgrades as though they were single transactions. For example, the Installed Software view has an Action column that displays upgrades as well as installs or removals.

sect1.para: To remove an item from the list of pending transactions, select it and click Cancel or right-click it and click Cancel.

When you are done choosing actions, click the Run Now button. The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will then check to see if additional actions are required. For example, if you attempt to install a new spelling dictionary, but you do not have the spelling tool, you will need to install the spelling tool as well as the dictionary.

The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will present you with a list of the actions that it is about to take, and ask you to confirm or cancel. If you are satisfied with the set of actions, click Continue.

tip.title: Use a Mirror for Faster Downloads
tip.para: For best performance, select a mirror near you. To learn how to choose a mirror, and why mirrors can give you a faster download, read .

sect1.title: Seven Ways of Looking at Software
sect1.para: Along the top of the right side of the window are seven tabs that give you different views of your system:

listitem.para: This is the view you will see when you start the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client. The Updates view displays updates to software that you have installed and that is in catalogs to which you are subscribed.
This view displays software that is installed on your computer.
This view displays software that is available to be installed on your computer.
This view lets you search the largest possible list of packages: those installed on your system, and those available for installation in all catalogs.
This view displays Bundles that are installed on your computer.
This view displays a list of actions you have performed in the past.
This view displays a detailed list of upcoming software transactions you have chosen. To perform them, click the Run Now button in the upper left hand corner of the window.

tip.title: Refresh
tip.para: Click the Refresh button to cause the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client to communicate with the ZENworks Server and get the lists of catalogs, packages, etc., that the device has access to.

sect2.title: Perform Updates
sect2.para: When you start the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client it will show you a list of software packages that you can update. An update notice is only shown for software that you already have installed, that is in a catalog to which you are subscribed, and for which there is a newer version than what you already have. New software, and new versions of software that you have but that is in a catalog to which you do not subscribe, is not part of the update screen.
If you do not see any updates, make sure that you are subscribed to the right catalogs.

Each package is displayed with the following information:
Action
The action you are performing for this package. This entry will be blank if you are neither installing nor removing it. If you have selected an action, it will have an installation or removal icon. You can click the blank space to perform an action (install a package if it is not installed, remove a package if it is installed), or click the icon to cancel the action.
Importance
The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will indicate how important it is for you to install this update. From least to most important, an update can be listed as minor, feature, suggested, urgent, or necessary.
Catalog
The name of the catalog in which this package is shipped.
New Version
The version number for the updated package. Note that version numbers do not count by digits, but instead use numbers separated by a period (.). In other words, version 1.10 is newer than version 1.9. You can remember this by referring to "one point ten" instead of "one point one zero."
Current Version
The version number of the software you have installed now.

To perform a simple update of software that is already on your system:
Select one or more packages in the list of available updates.
Mark the selected packages for installation by clicking the Mark for Installation button.
Click the Run Now button to have the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client perform the updates.

tip.title: Update All
tip.para: You can also click the Update All button to select and update all pending updates.

sect2.title: Remove Software on My Computer
sect2.para: To uninstall software that is on your computer now, click the Installed Software tab. The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will display a list of the software that is on your system now.

Select packages for removal and click Mark for Removal or click the space next to the package in the Action column. When you are finished, click the Run Now button, or select another view to choose more transactions.
Each package is displayed with the following information:

listitem.para: The action you are performing on this package.
The name of the catalog in which this package is shipped.
The name of the package.
The version number of the software you have installed now.

sect2.para: There are three ways to change the items in the list:

listitem.para: Choose from the list of catalogs to show only the software that comes from a particular catalog.
Choose from the list of software sections to show only the software of that type. Some catalogs do not use section divisions.
You can also search for a word or word fragment in the packages and their descriptions by typing into the text box above the list of packages.

sect2.para: For this view and for the Search view, you will have the following additional search options:

listitem.para: Check this box to search in package descriptions as well as package names.
Select Any Word for a broad search that matches any of the words you enter in the text box, or All Words to find only matches that contain all the words you enter.
Select Substrings to search for word fragments, or Whole Words to search for whole words only. Package names are rarely whole words, so this is mostly useful for package descriptions.

sect2.title: Search for Software
sect2.para: To look at the broadest possible range of software, and to find new software to install, click the Search tab. This will not immediately display a list of all available software. You must first search for the software you want to see. If you really want to see every available piece of software, enter a blank search in the search box.
To search for software, select one or more criteria for your search. You can choose:

listitem.para: Narrow your search to a specific catalog. If you do not select anything, you will search in all catalogs to which you are subscribed.
The type of software you are looking for, such as Productivity or Imaging. The default is to search in all sections.

You can search for packages that are not installed, packages that are installed, packages that you have installed but for which a newer version is available, or for packages of any status. The default is to search for all packages.
Type words or word fragments to search for, and then press Enter.

sect2.para: The advanced search options are the same as in My Computer. See for more information.
In the Search view, each package is displayed with the following information:

listitem.para: The action you are performing on this package.

Indicates whether you have the software installed and if so, whether an update is available. If you do not have the software, the value is listed as not installed. If you have the same version of the software as the one listed, the status will be installed. If you have a different version, the listed package will be described as older or newer than the installed version.
The name of the catalog in which this package is shipped.
The column with the lock icon indicates whether the package is cryptographically signed.
The name of the software package.
The version number of the package.

sect2.title: View Past Transactions with History
sect2.para: The history view displays a list of your past transactions. That is, each time you install, remove, or upgrade a piece of software, it's recorded here.
The history information is taken from the logs of the Red Carpet Daemon, rcd. It includes transactions made with the rug command line tool, but not changes made with dpkg, apt-get, or rpm.
It displays the following information about each transaction:

listitem.para: The time and date when the transaction occurred.
Whether you upgraded, installed, or removed the software.
The user who performed the action. In most cases, this will be root, but you may allow other users to use the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client.
The name of the software package involved in the transaction.
For upgrades and removals, this is the version of the software you had installed before the transaction. For installs, this entry is blank.
For Installs and Upgrades, this displays the version of the software after the transactions. For removals, this entry is blank.

sect2.para: To change the displayed list, you can choose one or more of the following criteria:

listitem.para: Normally, the History view shows you all transactions. You may choose instead to display just installations, removals, or upgrades.

Normally, the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will show you transactions performed by all permitted users. If you have allowed other users to use the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client, you may choose to display just their actions. If you have not allowed any other users to change the system, the only option here will be All.
Normally, the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will show you the transactions in the last thirty days. You can choose a longer or shorter time frame if you wish..

sect2.title: The Detailed Transaction View
sect2.para: The left side of the main ZENworks Linux Management Update Client window shows you a list of transactions you have selected, but it doesn't have room to give you a lot of detail. For more information about your pending transaction list, click the Pending Actions tab.
In addition to the action and package name available in the concise view, the detailed transaction view lets you see the package version number and the amount of disk space taken up by the package.

sect1.title: ZENworks Linux Management Update Client Preferences
sect1.para: To open the preferences window, click Edit Preferences . The window has four tabbed pages: General, Cache, Daemon, and Advanced.

sect2.title: General Preferences
sect2.para:
You can set the following preferences here:
Interval to Refresh Catalog Data
Specify how often you want to refresh catalog data. The default is two hours.
Require Package Signatures
ZENworks Linux Management ships software with a cryptographic signature. Unless you absolutely trust your server, you should leave this setting on for increased security.
Maximum Number of Packages to Download at Once
If possible, the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client will download several packages at once in order to make the best use of your network connection. If you have a very fast connection, you can increase this number. If you are sharing your connection with others, you can reduce it.
Enable Package Rollback
Select this option to allow for packages to be rolled back. When you upgrade or remove software, the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client normally deletes the earlier version of the packages. If you select this option, earlier versions of packages are not deleted, and you can roll back the software contained in them.
Use a Proxy
If your network uses an HTTP proxy, check this box, then specify the proxy URL. If necessary, also specify your username and password. Because the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client does not depend on a particular desktop, this setting must be entered independently of the GNOME desktop proxy setting.

sect2.title: Cache Preferences
sect2.para:
The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client stores downloaded files so that if you quit or cancel an operation, you can resume it quickly without downloading again. The Cache tab in the Preferences window lets you change cache handling behavior. Your options are:
Cache Downloaded Packages and Metadata
If you don't want to cache anything, uncheck this box. It is normally on.
Location of Cached Data
Specify the location where you will save cached files. By default, this is /var/opt/novell /zenworks/cache/zmd/web.
Expiration
Check the Cache Expires box to specify that the cache is emptied according to the settings you configure. This option is set by default. You can specify that the cache empties after a certain number of days or if its contents take up more than a certain amount of space. By default, this happens after 30 days or after the cache size reaches 300 MB. If you turn off cache expiration, packages will be kept until you delete them yourself by clicking the Empty Cache button.
At the bottom of the window, you can empty the package cache by clicking the Empty Cache button.

sect2.title: Advanced Preferences
sect2.para: To change the preferences on the Advanced page, select the check box or click the Setting in the Value column, then type the new setting. The options available in this section are:

varlistentry.term: Port to Listen On for Remote Clients

listitem.para: Specify the port to listen on for remote clients. The default is 2544.

varlistentry.term: Allow Clients to Connect Remotely to this Daemon

listitem.para: This setting is enabled by default.

varlistentry.term: The Number of Milliseconds to Delay Before Retrying a Download

listitem.para: The default setting is 2000 milliseconds.
The default setting is Min.

varlistentry.term: How Long Before Sending Delayed Actions, in Seconds

listitem.para: The default setting is 900 seconds.

varlistentry.term: Number of Seconds until HTTP Requests Timeout

listitem.para: The default setting is 1800 seconds.

varlistentry.term: Time of Day to Refresh Inventory

listitem.para: The default setting is 00.00:00 (midnight).

varlistentry.term: How Long to Wait between Retries of a Service Addition, in Seconds

listitem.para: The default setting is 300 seconds.

varlistentry.term: Whether of Not Verified SSL Certificates are Required

listitem.para: This setting demands that the ZENworks Linux Management Server have an identity certificate that is verified by external authority organizations. An external certificate is expensive and most servers will not have one. The default setting for this option is enabled.

varlistentry.term: The Maximum Number of Download Retries

listitem.para: The default setting is 3.
The default setting is empty, which means "all."

sect2.para: If you require finer control over the operation of the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client, you may want to edit the configuration files, as described in the man pages for rug, rcd, and rcd.conf.

sect1.title: Using the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client with Remote Systems
sect1.para: The ZENworks Linux Management Update Client may be used with remote systems running the Red Carpet Daemon, rcd. You will need to have an account with the daemon on the remote system.

To add an rcd account on the remote system, you must log in to that system as root, and use the rug user-add -U username -P password command. Then, you may administer the system without logging in as root.

To connect to a remote system, do the following:
Click FileConnect to Daemon.
Click Connect to a Remote System.
Select the remote server.
Enter your user name and password.
Click the Connect button.
Once you are connected you can view and administer the system as you would a local one, in accordance with the privileges granted to your account.
You can also use the rug command to administer a remote system. For information on the command line Red Carpet tools, use the man rug command.

sect1.title: Adding and Activating Services
sect1.para: Using the ZENworks Linux Management Update Client, you can use multiple servers for a single client. Each server is called a service.

To add a service, do the following:
Click EditServices.
Click Add Service.
Type the service URL, select the service type from the drop-down list, then type the registration key (optional).
Click OK to add the service.

To activate a service, do the following:
Click FileActivate.
Select the service from the drop-down list, type an e-mail address (or ensure that it is correct), then enter an activation code (optional).
Click Activate.
